The big fight sc=
enes in samurai swashbucklers used to unfold like
dance numbers, with the h=
ero as the prima, the attackers as the corps
de ballet. The audience was ex=
pected to admire the virtuoso

g the absence of blood,

Now the samu=
rai movie and its variants are back, but the model has

Hiroyuki Nakano's "Red Shadow," Hideyuki

Resurrection)" and Ryuhei Kitamura's

 Kabuki or ballet. The fighters

hysiques, but little depth

 a series of fight

de (or

er
of the bad guys are left to duel it out. The ending, unlike the final
"b=
oss" stage of a game, is a foregone conclusion.

Ten Shimoyama's "Shinobi,"=
 with its story of two warring ninja clans
in the early days of the Tokugaw=
a era, follows this game formula --
but with differences that make it a cut=
 above the genre run. A
king-of-all-media type who has directed everything =
from TV dramas to a

ythic quality
of Zhang Yimou's "Hero" or Ang Lee's "Crouching Tiger, Hidden=
 Dragon"

most Japanese films in this genre settle for the surface flash and
dazzle =
of the arcade. Shimoyama may be aiming at the same teen gamer

akes his material more seriously.

Also, the effects supplied by CG directo=
r Hiroyuki Hayashi are in the

ly for eye-popping

g over a

(Yukie Nakama), pierces a foe with her glance (her eyes changing color

the process) and shorts out his synapses, in a sequence that

nimated medical drawing in hyper-realistic 3-D.

These and other feats deri=
ve from the ninjas' training and abilities,

erpowers. Impossibly exaggerated, yes;

y defeat each other more with

ain, not the standard

Finally, Yukie Nak=
ama, a TV drama queen whose film work has been on

des dynamism, passion and sensuality, as

of Zhang Ziyi. The usual strategy

cingly (Aya Ueto in

en she is being

inja

She plays Oboro, a granddaughter of =
Ogen (Lily), the matriarch of the

nd falls in love with
Gennosuke, the son of Danjo Koga (Minoru Terada), the=
 leader of the
Koga clan. Living in the remote mountains, these two clans h=
ave, over
the centuries, perfected the arts of ninjutsu (or shinobi), which=
 is
far beyond the reach of mere mortals. They are also ancestral rivals
an=
d, under the order of Hanzo Hattori (Yutaka Matsushige), chief ninja
to Sho=
gun Tokugawa Ieyasu, are forbidden to exchange secret techniques
-- not tha=
t they would anyway.

Seeking to consolidate Tokugawa rule and seeing the t=
wo clans as a
threat to it, a powerful Tendai priest and Tokugawa adviser, =
Nankobo
Tenkai (Renji Ishibashi), schemes to set them against each other. H=
e
commands the two clans to each choose five champions who will battle

Both Oboro and =
Gennosuke are selected as champions, but neither are

lly, of each other's position. Also, Gennosuke

intentions and refuses to take part in the

egin to fall, he is forced into

o battle at least one Iga

The 10 contestants in this ultim=
ate death match are radically

y and each other, such as

he Kogas, who can

 Yashamaru

alent

The most memorable, however, are =
ones with the closest relationships

vely-but-creepy Kagero (Tomoka

 sweet on Gennosuke, and

nja master who knows

=

For those less interested in the emotional interplay than the action,
"Shi=
nobi" has much to offer beyond the usual wirework leaps and
bounds. Action =
director Yuji Shimomura has created fresh variations on
familiar ninja stun=
ts that will have hard-core genre fans doing "did I

.

"Shinobi" does not require shinbo (patience): It flies across the
screen=
 and ends, after all the mayhem, with a poignant moment of
remembrance and =
hope. Super ninjas may not be forever, but love endures.
